section.title: Present continuous and Present simple
section.sectiontitle: We use the Present continuous for something happening at this moment or something happening in the present period, but perhaps not at this moment.
section.text2a: We're studying French at school this term.
section.sectiontitle2: We use the Present simple for actions which are generally/usually true or for habits and routines.

section.title: Present continuous and Present simple
section.sectiontitle: We don't use the Present continuous for verbs describing mental states, e.g. believe, know, understand or with verbs connected with likes/dislikes, e.g. like, love, want.
section.text2: <FONT COLOR='#FC214C'>NOT</FONT>: Are you wanting an ice cream?
section.sectiontitle2: We don't use the Present continuous for verbs connected with possession, e.g. have, own, possess.
section.text3: <FONT COLOR='#FC214C'>NOT</FONT>: I'm not owning a computer.
section.text4: <FONT COLOR='#FC214C'>NOT</FONT>: She's having a new car.

section.title: Present continuous and Present simple
section.sectiontitle: In the Present continuous positive we use I am, he/she/it is, you/we/they are + -ing. We usually use the short form.
section.text2: We are living in Ireland at the moment.
section.text2a: We're living in Ireland at the moment.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative, we use I'm not, he/she/it is not, you/we/they are not + -ing . We usually use the short form.

section.title: Present continuous and Present simple
section.sectiontitle: We use am I, is he/she/it, are you/we/they + verb + -ing for the question form.
section.text1a: Is she doing her homework? Yes, she is.
section.text2a: Are you watching this programme? No, I'm not.
